text:
Once UNIX got real traction, from the
mid '70s onwards

I thought, well, it's only a matter of
time [until] they've got to give them the Turing
Award. And it happened, I think, in late '83.

They were given the [ACM] 
Turing award jointly. I think that

the formal presentation,
which required a sort of little

accompanying paper to go with it,
didn't happen until 1984.

But it really was an amazing piece 
of work that went with it.
A lot of people couldn't understand why

it was a bombshell. But it really, really is.
The ACM award is given for outstanding

achievements in any area
of computer science. So, yes, people like

Maurice Wilkes in the uk won it.
People like Steven Kleene

and [Michael] Rabin, and so on, who were all 
into regular expressions,

Turing machines, all that kind of stuff.
All this very worthy theoretical stuff

had won the Turing ACM award.
A lot of us began to wonder, though,

whether they might
just be so impressed by UNIX as a

down-to-earth achievement, that 
Dennis Ritchie and Ken Thompson,

the two authors of it, might get jointly
honoured, we hoped. Because they deserved it.

It was an amazing achievement. Oh! and
by the way,

if any of you want to know what happened
with Unix and in what order
I can only point you at my fellow Computerphile

person, Brian Kernighan. He's written lots
of books, of course, [e.g.] about C
[which] he co-authored with Dennis, but this one

"A History and a Memoir" i think is the one
that i've dipped into most [shows front cover of book]

nd certainly for preparing these recent
videos because he basically -- all right

he's a Bell Labs insider [with] a little 
bit of [pro Bell] bias, maybe, but basically

he gives an unvarnished view
about what happened, and in what order,

and why did Berkeley have to 
happen after

Bell Labs had set the ball rolling and
all this. And right on

through to the breakup [of AT&T] and 
eventually you just had to have something like
Linux.  It was the only way everybody was going

to be able to progress.
So what did Dennis and Ken do?

And what did Ken say in his
acceptance speech

which was so remarkable? The title is:
"Reflections on Trusting Trust"

First of all a half-page thank
yous to everybody who helped me.

I'm not currently involved (in late '84) in
any more development work on the latest UNIX.
[I've] left that to others. Version 7 [of UNIX] has

been out for almost 5 years now.
But what i want to do is to use this
opportunity to get you all to think about something

which has now come upon us.
You will be clear that Dennis and I have
developed C, largely as a system implementation
language. And, what's more to the point, we have

written the whole of the UNIX operating 
system in C,

Can you trust us not to have hidden
something deadly

inside of the C that we are using all
the time?

And most people say well .... this view you
see that

compilers were benign. You know they
were, wonderful, helpful things

that enable you to get from a high-level
language down to a runnable binary

in terms that you could more or less
understand. We've done lots of

T-diagrams to explain how this works. You
know

[we have a ] C compiler available as a binary. [It] takes
input statements,

puts out a certain [near-binary] output.  That's what a
compiler is for.
It's to provide a binary or near-binary object

that's easier to produce than writing at
Assembler code level.

Everybody understands that. But, backing 
off from all of this a bit, what

Ken asked - although he doesn't
make it quite as blatant as this - but if

you read and re-read and re-read and
re-read (!)

this four-page article until you've
understood it all,

and it "does your head in". The question
you end up

asking yourself is: "Have we opened a
Pandora's Box" here?

Because what Ken is saying is
something like this:

"What happens if your compiler has been 
engineered to be one of the bad guys ?"
And you think: "Oh, my Lord,

if the operating system is written in C
and C is commonplace, and people

understand C and now it'll work with
it -  it becomes a very powerful weapon for

mucking with the Operating System
if you're a good enough C programmer.

So, basically, Ken says: "Yes, consider the
following:

i may or may not have done the following"
[note from DFB I think he actually has, or did]
How would you feel if I make my compiler

ask ( of the C program that's flowing
through it)

I keep an eye on it and I say is this
person just

messing about compiling up "Hello World"
so you can amaze everybody with your

first binary program. It says "Hello World"
[when executed ] Or is it something more serious?

Is this person trying to recompile
the whole kernel of the Operating System

because, maybe as a "bad" compiler, I ought
to say I've got a view about this

so the first trick he says is how do you
know i'm not watching the code go by

and when i say to myself: "He's
recompiling me -
the Operating System"  I intervene and put in

some extra compiled source code
which allows me to get into the system
and log in as super user without knowing the

super-user password.
So, I will put in an extra little bit

that says [if] are you a super user as [via] an
ordinary user [then]

OK, go through the normal password
mechanism. Otherwise

when i say [ask for] "Password",  if you give me - what
shall we say Sean:  "abracadabra" ?

If you say "abracadabra", i open up the
entire system for you.

You can do absolutely everything.
How would you feel about that? And then

when he's got through that, on Part 1
of the paper, saying

"How about a rogue operating system that
we've propagated all over the world now?"
I, Ken Thompson know the magic super super *super*

password that will get me in anyway.
[If] some angry person has come up and says

"There is bad code in your C compiler
it will let people do horrible things"

And they say to you
"show me the [C] source now!". If you're foolish

you show them the [amended] source and they see
the [extra] code and that's it.

But what happens -- and this, for those of
you who watched it, is a bit like going
back to T-diagrams, what happens if the thing

effectively says: "I'm going to
squirt some extra source [text] for the rogue

code into [the output] every time you recompile the C
compiler with itself. I won't put it in

every program because people will detect
it and will get mightily upset.

But i promise you ... I mean the the binary
from a C-ompiler recompile is pretty big
I will hide in there the [extra] rogue source

code in a string of characters
which, if I trigger it and reactivate it,

will get compiled
as part of a C-compiler recompilation.

Are you still with me ?!
... and will always propagate itself

into the [generated binary] programs. And you might say well
but ... but .... you come along with a [new] version

of the C compiler that's got that bad
code and you will recompile it [without the bad insert]
And i say "Yes, but at the base of your T-diagram

is a still a [binary] rogue version of you
that you are using to [re-]compile yourself!"

Because until your new one [i.e. your new binary] is created
you've got no hope

but to use what the [software] company has given
you, or what Ken has given you.

And Ken is saying, basically, [that] if you are
happy with that ....

"Am i a nice sort of person - would I do
this to you,

maybe i would  ...?".  There's very good reasons 
that this has been described by a

gentleman called
Cory Doctorow who describes it as:

" ... total f***ing bombshell !"
What he's saying is that ...

if somebody angrily comes up to you and
doesn't understand

says "Look - 
I'm going to really punch you up and

kill you unless you give me the source
code to this compiler and show me it's clean"

So, you show them clean source code 
[with no sign of the 'bug'] and

[you] say: "Go on, recompile it".
And it compiles and it's fine.

But then when you run [i.e. execute] that compiled
recompile of the binary

it still [is compromised] and  allows you to get 
in as super-user.

But you knocked the pieces of source code out
that enables you to go super-user.

You're not recompiling [ that 'back door bug' ]
The answer is it's embedded so deeply

because of [previous] versions of the compiler
ensuring that as you bootstrap up you
still propagate that code even if the user

hasn't said that they want it 
(if you see what i mean)

So, it's deadly
because it's embedded and hidden in the

old *binary* - not in the [current] source 
You can masquerade [and assert]

that the source is OK: "Honestly 
this source corresponds to this binary :-)

It's a bit like trying to get rid of
Japanese Knot Weed in your garden.

You know there's always enough spores in the
ground

from previous [invasions] that they will 
reinfect you.

Yeah! And i suppose you might tear your
hair out and say

"How can i cope with this?!" And the answer
is - and i'm going to leave it to

Sean and the 'Computerphile' organization
- tentacles everywhere (!)

to find somebody suitable to follow me
and to say: "This is still an issue!"

And in fact I think Ken invented the word 
'trojan' for this [situation].
[He] said: "This thing is masquerading as 'Oh! I'm

just a perfectly innocent C compiler' "
But it isn't ! It's a Trojan Horse.

There's trapdoors in the underside of it
that will let you do these awful things

and enable you to --
because of its self-replicating capability
-- will enable you to propagate for evermore.
And he basically just says: " Consider ... !"

It's sobering.
>> Sean: So this was 1984 this came out 
>> DFB: [Yes] this was 1984 ...

>> Sean: Truly Orwellian 
>> DFB: Truly Orwellian. The
article we're

pointing you [to] by Cory Doctorow was
published in 2020.

All i'm saying is -- [and I] am not part of the
great UNIX Security industry - I know nothing (!)

I'm just telling you what Ken did originally. 
But what Doctorow was

saying is [that] 
this is still a big big issue.

Because if you consider what kind of things
you could propagate

using techniques like this ...  if you were a
'bad' company

You could for example be a supplier of
printer inks

and start interrogating your printer and
say "Are you running the right

sort of ink or is it 'rogue' ink?  Because if 
so we're going to disable your print routines"

Or alternatively [if you've] got one of
these newfangled [by 1984 standards!]

CD-ROM burners in your computer what
happens if it's made by a company that's

subverted the system software in UNIX in
such a way

that it won't let you copy rogue CDs
that haven't been made with its own facilities.
Stuff like that. The possibilities are limitless.
